title: The new woman and her bicycle
creator: Opper, Fredrick Burr, 1857-1937
description: The central figure is a confidently posed woman in exaggerated, fashionable bloomer-style cycling attire. She stands tall with her hands in her pockets, wearing puffed sleeves, a fitted jacket, plaid knee-length bloomers, stockings, and heeled shoes. On the top left a older woman rides a bike, labeled as a “new” servant girl. The middle left A woman hauls laundry in a large basket mounted on her bicycle, labeled “The ‘new’ Washerwoman.” Two men stand beside a pile of leaves watching her. Bottom left A woman pedals a bicycle pulling a small carriage containing a baby holding a parasol, labeled “The ‘new’ Nurse-Girl.” Top center A framed portrait of a woman cycling is propped behind the centeral figure. Top right a woman rides ahead of. a man, who is on a tricycle carrying a bundle; it is labeled “The ‘new’ Suburban Lady, starting for a long ride.” Middle right young  women up ride in a line, one playing a bass drum, one holding a tambourine, the other reading as she cycles. Labeled as “The ‘new’ Society young Ladies.”Bottom right: A grieving widow dressed in mourning clothes rides to a cemetery. Off to the side is a bicycle leaning against a gravestone. Labeled “The ‘new’ Widow.”
source: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington, D.C. 20540 USA http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.print

title: Some popular conceptions that the wheeling mania will change
creator: Oppen, Fredrick Burr, 1857-1937
description:
This is a full-color, two-page satirical cartoon spread.The illustration is divided into several comic vignettes arranged around a large central scene of . Each vignette depicts imagined consequences of the “wheel craze,” with lively linework and bright pastel colors with mostly blues, yellows, browns, and greens. In the centeral illustration A large group of cyclists race  across a rough, reddish landscape.
around the riders there are hordes of “red devils” representing danger or mischief.
The riders struggle over rocks, turning the scene into a wild stampede.
source: Library of congress prints and photographs division Washington, D.C. 20540

title: Fashion, world of- Mannequins- with bike
creator: N/A
description: A mannequin with a blonde curcled hair and striped mmatching shirt and skirt site posed on a rough log in the foreground. Behind it, a bicycle is placed, its frame and wheels partially visible. The wheels have no spokes and are covered in flowers.
source: New York Public Library (NYPL) Digital Collections.

title: Biking across town
creator: N/A
description: James Irvine and Batchel riding high-wheel bicycles (penny-farthings) on a paved road, with various buildings and structures in the background.
source: Los Angeles Public Library, Photo Collection

title: Betzy Kjelsberg, 1891, in Drammen. Was among the first to start riding on a bike.
creator: N/A
description: Portrait photograph of Betzy Kjelsberg sitting on bicycle with both feet on pedals. She is wearing a dark, long skirt and a bodice with large puffed sleeves, a high collar, and a dark  cap.
source: The New York Public Library, Digital Collections
